awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: NSF Summer School on Computational Modeling of Disordered Materials for Historically Black Colleges and Universities
awd_abstract_narration:
SUMMARY

This award supports an intensive training workshop for students and faculty members from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) and Minority Serving Institutions (MSI) on computational modeling of complex materials, with an emphasis on the fundamental concepts of physics, chemistry and materials science. The participants will learn and employ a variety of modern structural modeling techniques and widely used computer simulation methodologies to understand and analyze the properties of highly complex and technologically important disordered materials. The workshop will adopt a lecture-laboratory approach, whereby each lecture is followed by hands-on computational "laboratory" exercises, aimed at illustrating how information from the lecture can be directly employed for practical simulations of complex materials. The topics to be addressed in the laboratory exercises are: structural modeling techniques on the length scale of atoms, analyses of structural properties, geometry optimization, electronic and vibrational properties, as well as thermodynamic properties of different types of disordered materials. The participants will also be introduced to the fundamentals of emerging data-centric and machine-learning techniques in materials modeling. The workshop will: (i) expose students to a wide range of state-of-the-art computer simulation techniques, and the applications of these techniques to real-world problems; (ii) bridge the gap between the standard teaching curriculum at the undergraduate and graduate levels and the actual expertise and knowledge that are needed for practicing computational materials science even at its basic level; (iii) develop collaborative initiatives between HBCUs and state-funded and private universities to initiate research in computational modeling of complex materials. The PIs will provide post-workshop support for a period of six months so that participants may develop small publishable research projects on their return to their home institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A highly successful summer workshop/school on Computational
Modeling of Disordered Materials was organized in the
Gulf Park campus of the University of Southern Mississippi
at Long Beach, MS. The workshop was held on June 3-7, 2019 in collaboration
with the University of Texas at Arlington. Faculty members and
undergraduate and graduate students from 15 HBCUs and MSIs from
all over the USA participated in the school. A total of 28
participants, consisting of undergraduate and graduate students,
faculty members, and 6 invited speakers in the field of physics,
chemistry, and computer science attended the workshop.

The major activities involved an in-depth 7-day training
program in theory and computational modeling of
materials and basics of computational Physics. A team
of six (6) national experts on computational modeling of
complex materials delivered fifteen (15) lectures that
included topics from Monte Carlo (MC) and molecular
dynamics (MD) simulations, density functional theory (DFT)
of solids, kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) methods, and
applications of bio-inspired computing to complex
materials modeling, using swarm intelligence (SI),
neural networks, and differential evolution (DE).

An essential part of the workshop was to provide an
introductory training in using linux operating system
in workstation-class laptop computers. This was found
to be vitally important and useful as many of the HBCU
students and faculty members did not have prior experience
in working with linux operating systems. Following an
intensive one-day training, the participants completed
courses in Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics simulations,
advanced modeling techniques using stochastic
and classical deterministic  approaches. An introduction to
density functional theory, using freely available NWCHEM
and SIESTA software,  was given with an emphasis on solving
practical problems.  In addition to these, the participants
were given training to learn and employ a number of utility
programs, which are useful in modeling complex materials.
At the end of the workshop, the participants learned the
following:

a) Handling of linux operating systems for high-performance
computation;

b) Knowledge in conventional simulation methods, for example, Monte
Carlo and molecular dynamics simulation, for computational modeling
of materials;

c) Introduction to first-principles density-functional calculations
of molecules, clusters, solids, and disordered materials using freely
available software (such as, SIESTA and NWCHEM);

d) Advanced modeling techniques, for example, evolutionary or
bio-inspired computing in optimization or structure determination of
complex molecules, clusters, and disordered  materials.

e) The organizers of the workshop (Biswas and Atta-Fynn) published two research papers in peer-reviewed international journals (in Physical Review B) on topics which were developed during the course of the workshop.

A follow-up workshop was planned for the summer of 2020 but the
outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic led to the cancellation of the
workshop. Participants were primary interested to attend in person
but the health and safety regulations at that time due to COVID-19
required to us to cancel the workshop.

Additional information can be found by visiting the workshop
website at

https://saraswati.phys.usm.edu/hbcu2
